THE TRANSPORT SECTOR Economic Growth and Impact 1.1 During 1980-93, economic growth in China averaged 9.4 percent a year, as the country adopted an open-door policy and benefited from foreign investment. As a result, demand for transport increased enormously. In 1993 alone, freight and passenger traffic grew at an average of 7 percent and 10 percent, respectively. Moreover, freight volumes in China have historically been high. To produce one dollar of econornic output, China handles 50 percent more ton- kilometers (t.km) of traffic than India and Brazil, primarily due to the long distances between the country's coal reserves and its relatively large, coal-dependent heavy-industry sector. A large gap between transport supply and demand consequently emerged. 1.2 To meet this demand, the country has been expanding its transport system substantially, but despite considerable growth, the transport network remains one of the sparsest in the world compared with the area and population it serves. The main reason for this sector's underdevelopment is the relatively low level of transport investment, which averaged only 1.3 percent of gross national product during 1981-91, as compared with 2 to 3 percent for other countries such as India, the Republic of Korea and Brazil. As a result, congestion and bottlenecks are routine on various parts of the systern, service is often poor and rationed, and the economy has suffered losses. Traffic 1.3 Growth. During 1982-92, freight traffic has grown at 8.1 percent a year and passenger traffic at almost 10 percent a year, as indicated by turnover volume of traffic (see Tables 1.1 and 1.2). Highway freight traffic expanded more than the other modes, at 14.7 percent, compared with 6.6 percent for rail traffic and 9.5 percent for coastal and inland waterway traffic. Intercity passenger travel per capita, despite rapid increases, remains very low, at about two thirds the level for India-primarily due to severe capacity constraints. Although air travel is rapidly expanding and grew by more than 21 percent a year during 1982-92, it still represents a small share of total traffic, as most long-distance trips are made by rail. 1.4 Modal Distribution. Although the railway's share of traffic has declined over the last decade as the share of road and inland waterways (IWW) traffic has grown, rail transport still dominates freight and passenger traffic in China. In 1992, about 57 percent of freight and 46 percent of passenger traffic turnover was attributable to rail, with the remainder moved by road, IWW, coastal shipping, pipeline, and civil aviation. This preemninence of the railway is due in part to the past dependence of the Chinese economy on heavy industry and in part to the relatively long transport distances. In the case of passenger transport, dominance of the railway is due to the poor quality and inadequate capacity of the
 - 2 - road system and intercity bus services, the virtual absence of pnvate automobiles, and the limited use of civil aviation. The movement toward a market economy will increase demand for market-responsive transport services, favoring a shift to road transport but still leaving a growing market for the relatively low-cost inland waterways and rail transport systems. Transport Reforms 1.5 In the past decade, China's economic reforms have aimed to increase economic efficiency through measures designed to reduce national government intervention in the production and distribution process, reduce the Government's deficits and subsidies to state-owned enterprises, and open the economy by expanding trade and allowing further participation of private and collective enterprises. In the transport sector, several reforms have been undertaken in line with these objectives--many with Bank assistance. Notably, the Government has: (a) allowed decentralization of operations in 1985, commercalization in 1989, and a market economy in 1993; (b) reduced the extent of commodity price distortions by (i) decreasing the volumes of commodities produced in the State Plan, and (ii) raising the in-plan prices of commodities closer to market levels; (c) increased the tariffs charged by state transport enterprises, including railway, highway and waterway, to levels approaching their long-run marginal costs; (d) encouraged provincial governments to develop many local railways, which now total some 4,400 route-km and interconnect with the national standard gauge network; (e) allowed private individuals and collective and township enterprises to provide passenger and freight transport services on roads and inland waterways, and encouraged provincial and national authorities to develop transport systems with private sector financing; (f) carried out major structural reforms in the organization and management of civil aviation and in the ports, leading to increased financial autonomy and accountability, and to less central government controls thus paving the way for introduction of competitive services; (g) reduced operating and capital subsidies for major infrastructure services, through higher cost-recovery and increased reliance on user-funded capital construction; and (h) encouraged the introduction of more modem technology in the transport system primarily by improving rolling stock technology in the railways; enhancing container and bulk handling capacity in the ports; improving road pavement design and geometric standards for the expansion of motorization in the highway subsector, and increasing the use of computerized data processing and planning techniques in operations in all modes.
 -3 - The Remaining Challenges 1.6 In the future, these reform initiatives will need to be expanded and pursued even more vigorously. In addition, much more needs to be done on the level of investment, intermodal planning and pricing to put in place a national transport system capable of meeting the transport needs of China's rapidly growing and changing economy. To alleviate transport bottlenecks and rationalize the transport system, the Government will need to take the following measures within the coming decade: (a) increase the total level of transport investment in relation to GNP, to expand capacity to meet the new traffic demands and to clear up the backlogs caused by past underinvestment; (b) aim for balanced investments among the major freight transport modes of railways, highways, and waterways in terms of optimal economic cost of transport; (c) realign further the prices of freight transport services and those of the major commodities, especially coal, to bring them closer to their real costs; (d) increase further the productivity of existing transport assets through technological modernization and management reforms; and (e) improve and expand the multimodal transport system, both across and within modes, with particular emphasis on more extensive use of containers. B. INLAND WATERWAYS TRANSPORT The Network 1.7 China has 5,800 rivers navigable for 110,200 km, 15 rivers over 1,000 km long and 12 lakes with an area greater than 1,000 km2. Nevertheless, the major IWW comprise only four rivers and one canal, which carry 80 percent of total IWW traffic. The Yangtze River system is by far the largest IWW. IWW Region km 1. Beijing-Hangzhou Grand Canal East 1,044 Total 92,766 1.8 China has a long history of using this extensive waterway network of rivers and lakes and of canal construction. Excavation of the Grand Canal, by connecting river tributaries, was started in about 480 BC. However, significant underfunding in this subsector has caused the
 - 4 - infrastructure and floating equipment to deteriorate badly, and reduced the net size of the navigable network from 172,000 km in 1960 to 148,400 km in 1970 and to 109,700 km in 1993. The lack of a multipurpose infrastructure development approach and methodology, and of coordination among the various ministries in charge of infrastructure also contributed to the IWW decline. For example, many hydropower dams have been built without consulting other interested agencies and without providing shiplocks to allow uninterrupted IWW transport. 1.9 Thus, between 1961 and 1991, IWW shrunk 36 percent, from 172,000 km to 109,700 km. Over the past decade, although the network size was almost unchanged, other modes registered positive growth. For example, from 1986 to 1993, the length of the national road network (class 1 and 2 roads) increased by 61 percent, from 203,800 km to 327,300 km, railway main lines grew by 8.2 percent, from 64,125 km to 69,412 km, while IWW grew by only by 0.7 percent, from 109,400 km to 110,200 km. Given China's highly congested transport environment, where the opportunity cost of the transport shortage is high, IWW are an extreme case of planning inefficiency and neglect of a valuable resource. Subsector Organization 1.10 Administration. The Ministry of Communications (MOC) provides nationwide policy guidelines, regulations, and the design, standards and financial support for IWW construction, with IWW administration carried out by provincial communications departments (PCDs), guided by MOC. The construction, maintenance and day-to-day management of the IWW infrastructure, however, has been delegated to local communications bureaus at the municipal, township and county levels. Since mid-1984, responsibility for 15 national ports has been decentralized to provincial and municipal governments. 1.11 Each river's IWW system is independently developed and operated, with no interaction among them. This means barges and vessels must navigate within just one IWW system, and barge types and convoy formations are unique to each. Except in the Yangtze River, channel depth is shallow, at less than 1 meter in about 50 percent of the IWW system. Only 8 percent can accommodate barges of 330 tons (t) or more. 1.12 Planning. MOC is responsible for the comprehensive master plan and investment strategies for the IWW system. Once approved by the State Council, the plan becomes the long- term development plan that provincial governments, responsible for engineering design, construction, operation and maintenance of the IWW system, follow. MOC coordinates overall planning and financial aid for constructing priority sections of the IWW, since most river construction involves more than one province and transport mode. 1.13 Financing. IWW construction and maintenance is not self-financing. The main source of revenue has been the waterway maintenance fee, levied as a percentage of the shipping companies' and private shipowners' gross revenues. These amounts permit only minimum channel maintenance by the PCDs, and MOC contributes to their costs. Recently, the PCDs have introduced a waterway construction fee that is calculated on a ton-km basis. With regard to the river ports, the local communication bureaus collect a port construction fee to partly finance their development, but again, it is not sufficient to sustain port development. The possibility of
 - 5 - collecting IWW fees directly from shipowners, based on the carrying capacity of the registered fleet, should be explored, as well as annual safety inspections and renewal of the vessel certificates and licenses. 1.14 The IWW Industry. Governments at all levels are focusing on developing demand- driven transport services. Traditional IWW services have been significantly commercialized with respect to shipping, shipbuilding and IWW port companies, and freight forwarding. 1.15 Competition among shipping companies already exists. They have been independent since the commercialization reform, and pay taxes to the central and provincial governments. However, state-owned companies have been carrying comparatively more cargo over the longer distances in larger barges. As more and more companies are privatized, it is expected that they will handle more cargo. In Guangxi, a province included in the proposed project, of the 260 companies operating, five are state-owned, 130 are collectives and 125 are private. The provinces have been making progress in providing free access to resources such as labor, fuel and materials. 1.16 While port infrastructure is owned by provincial and local governments, operations are increasingly carried out by independent companies. For example, in Zhejiang, another project province, two major public IWW ports at Hangzhou and Qianjiang are operated by financially and commercially independent companies. And, as there are about 200 privately owned berths compared with 80 public berths, this indicates that port operations are not restricted to government-owned entities. About 85 percent of Zhejiang's IWW traffic is now handled by the private sector. 1.17 Shipbuilding is being corporatized or commercialized, and public shipyards have become financially and commercially independent. Many collectively-owned shipyards and maintenance facilities are building and maintaining their own fleets, and those of others. For example, the Zhejiang Shipbuilding Industrial Corporation has about 50 shipbuilding and repair facilities, and builds about 60,000 dwt annually. In addition, many smaller collectively-owned facilities build for their own use. Competition in the shipbuilding industry is increasing. 1.18 Cargo owners are free to deal with any shipping companies they choose, and negotiate transport services and tariffs. And, with the move to a market economy, freight forwarding services are being liberalized and privatized. However, competition could be strengthened if there were (a) freedom of access to materials, repairs, and accessories at standardized prices, (b) access to bank credit, and (c) full freedom to hire labor (state-owned companies are still not free to hire or fire). C. MAJOR ISSUES IN THE IWW SUBSECTOR 1.19 The following critical issues constraining adequate development and management of the IWW network have been identified, and will need to be addressed in the context of the overall rationalization of China's transport system: (a) Inadequate Capital Investments. During the last four decades, less than 1 percent of total national investment in capital construction was allocated to the IWW. As a result,
 - 6 - most of the navigable channels were not maintained and/or improved, which caused the system to be underutilized and led to higher unit transport costs and lower safety standards; (b) Lack of Investment Coordination. Many dams and bridges financed through various government agencies were constructed without consultation with the IWW authorities, and without provision of shiplocks. This meant that ships could no longer use the waterways, and the navigable length of rivers declined by 36 percent during the past 30 years. (c) Lack of an Autonomous National IWW Agency. Critically needed coordination of the IWW subsector with other parts of the transport sector and with other sectors requires establishment of a fully authorized agency with its own budget to represent IWW interests at the national level and to develop, maintain and maximize use of the system. (d) Low Tariff Levels. For surface transport, the IWW has been identified as the most economic means to move low-valued bulk cargo. However, while IWW operating costs should be much lower than those of rail (by consuming 20 to 30 percent less energy), due to inadequate maintenance and poor operations, costs have risen. The proposed project would address some of these issues in the context of supporting an IWW reform program in three provinces. D. BANK GROUP PARTICIPATION 1.20 Transport Investments and Studies. The Bank Group has supported initiatives by the Government in the transport sector through loans and credits totaling $4.7 billion for 30 projects (Table 1.3). The dialogue between the Government and the Bank Group on transport sector operations and strategy has been strengthened through long-term strategy studies for railways, highways and ports development, and through project preparation activities and project-financed studies as well as sector studies carried out in collaboration with Chinese authorities. The Bank Group also conducted a srvey of the national water transport system in the mid-1980s, which reaffirmed the need to further exploit the large potential of the Chinese waterways. 1.22 Based on past project and sector work, the Bank has an opportunity to deepen its involvement and assist the Government in the design and implementation of institutional and sectoral reforms in areas such as strategy formulation, investment planning, pricing, financing, deregulation of transport services, operational efficiency, and transfer of advanced transport-related technology through training and provision of up-to-date equipment. Chinese authorities and the Bank Group are currently preparing a comprehensive transport sector strategy paper that is expected to help guide sector development in a consistent, cohesive policy framework. 1.23 With respect to IWW development, the sector strategy paper is expected to recommend IWW expansion when waterways offer the most economic means of heavy bulk freight transport in a corridor, and when intersectoral rationalization of services are beneficial to economic development. Recommendations for efficiency improvements are likely to include, among others, commercialization and corporatization of operating companies, introduction of competition and transparency, assurance of cost-based tariffs, transfer of modern technology and up-to-date approaches to operational and environmental matters, and improvement and expansion of multimodal transport facilities, particularly for containers. The proposed project was designed with a view to such a strategy. 1.24 The proposed project includes development of small hydropower stations in conjunction with construction of two dams, the latter to improve navigation by raising the river level. The Bank's highly successful involvement in the power sector supports the Government's ambitious sector reform program of enterprise commercialization and reduction of barriers to sector entry. Bank assistance to power companies combines investment in capacity expansion as well as institutional development, electricity conservation, and sector regulatory development. The Bank is also working with the Chinese authorities on ways to expand private financing of power infrastructure. 1.25 Lessons Learned in Implementation. As the proposed project would be the Bank's first IWW project in China, project preparation was guided by general lessons learned in previous projects throughout the transport sector, but particularly in ports, experience with IWW gained in other countries and lessons learned in the power sector. While implementation of Bank-supported projects has been generally satisfactory, management and quality of construction, project coordination, cost recovery, maintenance and tariff policies could have been improved. In the proposed project, to ensure the quality of construction and management, a project implementation unit is being formed, using the most qualified staff available and assisted by international and local consultants where appropriate. To ensure a high level of cost recovery, new tariff levels and the means to increase them periodically would be introduced under the project, with covenanted performance targets, to allow coverage of operating costs, debt service, maintenance and a contribution to future investment. For effective project coordination, a project liaison group would be established, comprised of implementing agency representatives. Since two of the project provinces, Hunan and Guangxi, are still relatively inexperienced with Bank projects, a
 - 8 - well-planned, time-phased training program has been included in the project to, inter alia, improve staff capabilities in civil works supervision, project management, and environmental assessment. 1.26 Bank involvement in IWW development worldwide has been limited to projects in Myaniar, Thailand, Bangladesh, Romania and what was formerly the Congo. These projects have indicated the need for technical assistance and training to improve implementation capabilities, substantial supervision early in the project-particularly regarding procurement and training, and promotion of cost consciousness and operating efficiency. These requirements have been met by the project design and proposed supervision arrangements. 1.27 Previous hydropower projects have also demonstrated the need for technical panels and consultants to enhance implementation quality. and acceleration of sector and enterprise reform to increase efficiency. The project therefore provides for a technical panel responsible for ensuring dam safety, agreement on adequate pricing of power supplied by the project, and an institutional and financial reform action plan to be carried out under the project to accelerate the reform process in the participating institutions.

Since this extensive subsector poses numerous challenges that will take some time to address, definition of the project area and the scope and types of activities to be financed had to be approached carefully. After lengthy discussion by the Government and the Bank, and studies of critical sections of China's transport system-including the Yangtze Economic Zone, the Southeast Coastal Region, the rapidly growing Guangdong area, and the transport implications of the country's energy reliance on coal-the Government and the Bank concurred that this initial IWW activity would be a well-balanced effort in both geographic and operational terms. *Improvements to the IWW system under the project would therefore be carried out both in the relatively rich coastal province of Zhejiang, where IWW bottlenecks have periodically brought segments of the area economy to a standstill, and in the poor, relatively neglected provinces of Hunan and Guangxi, where proposed IWW development would help open up the local economies by improving transport between the provinces and the Yangtze and Pearl Rivers, respectively. Completion of a river channel from Nanning City in Guangxi to booming Guangzhou in Guangdong would bring additional benefits to the economies of two other poor provinces in southwest China-Yunnan and Guizhou-which will soon have improved rail and road connections to Nanning. The proposed project is also balanced in terms of 'hardware" and 'toftware." Project infrastructure investments would be complemented by a substantial training and technical assistance program to support general institutional development and the implementation of an institutional and financial reform plan, consistent with market economics. The project is therefore designed to both promote and sustain China's development, and to further the reform agenda being pursued by the Government, with Bank support. B. With an average annual per capita income of Y 1,240 in 1992 (compared to the national average of Y 1,736 per year), Hunan contains a major north-south industrial corridor, along which are located five industrial cities (Zhuzhou, Yueyang, Changsha, Xiangtan and Hengyang, see map), which account for over half the province's output. The most important commodities are building materials, minerals and grains, which are shipped out of the province for both domestic consumption and export. Four rail lines and five state highways run the length of the corridor. Some sections of the rail lines are saturated and the others operate close to capacity. The lines extend from Beijing-Guangzhou, Zhejiang-Jiangxi, Hunan-Guizhou and Hunan-Guangxi and carry 69 percent of the freight and 55 percent of passenger traffic. The five highways also haul a large share (24 percent), carrying the railway's overflow. The Bank's recently approved Railways VII Project will electrify and upgrade the 1,044 km Wuhan-Guangzhou rail line, which is particularly congested. 2.7 The main river in the province, the Xiangjiang, also parallels the corridor, flowing from south to north, where it joins Dongting Lake and the Yangtze River. Hunan's major inland waterways are located along this river and could be an important transport route for nearly 800 km, from the city (and port) of Hengyang in the southern part of the province, to Zhuzhou, in the north. At this point, the river connects to a waterway section that has already been improved- extending to the Yangtze River and then to the sea. At present, since the waterway on the Hengyang-Zhuzhou section is shallow, navigation is poor and vessels are restricted to under 300 tons. Thus, its share of freight is limited (only 5.8 percent). Under the proposed project, upgrading the waterway would allow vessels to carry 1,000 tons, to match the vessel size accommodated on the upgraded stretch from Zhuzhou to the Yangtze. Also, the waterway's share of freight could be substantially increased (waterway traffic is estimated to grow by 3.4 percent a year) and it could offer a low-cost, environmentally sound alternative to rail and highway transport. 2.8 Guangxi. To do so, the IWW will need to: (a) operate under commercial principles, and (b) improve productivity and reduce costs. When these are realized, the IWW should be able to generate enough funds to cover all operating costs and debt service obligations and to contribute to future investments. Recent Reforms 2.13 Declining IWW performance is as much a matter of poor organization and management, lack of a market orientation, restrictive regulations, and insufficient attention to intermodal
 - 13 - coordination, as of shallow channels and outdated equipment, vessels and barges. The provincial governments in the three project provinces have already begun to recognize the larger problems they face, and have: (a) liberalized cargo allocation (no longer controlled by the PCDs); (b) improved free entry to the transport system and the related resources (fuel, labor); (c) liberalized waterway tariffs (allowing shipping companies to negotiate tariffs within 20 percent of those set by the pricing bureaus); and (d) commercialized and corporatized various operations, as evidenced by shipping companies, port corporations and shipbuilding industries. These are encouraging steps in the right direction. 2.14 While much more remains to be done (and some remaining challenges, particularly in regulatory reform, will require national-level decisions), it is significant that reforms have already been initiated in this comparatively neglected part of the transport system. This has occurred due to the existence of important conditions favoring development of a market-oriented IWW system in China, including: (a) a high level of decentralization; (b) rapid economic development and increasing transport demand (in contrast to the situation in most transition economies); (c) the acceptance even now of direct user charges (used to finance waterways maintenance and construction, lock and port construction), compared to the virtual absence of such fees even in parts of the United States and Europe; and (d) a fledgling private sector. Even so, a slow, incremental approach to IWW reform must be expected in China, where any change is normally tested in various locations before broader innovations are introduced. Incrementalism is also inevitable in the IWW, due to the system's highly decentralized operational responsibilities. 2.15 The proposed project represents a further step in the reform process by supporting creation of independent IWW companies and fostering improved financial performance through efficiency enhancements and cost-based pricing reforms.  -61- ANNEX A HYDROPOWER GENERATION A. HUNAN PROVINCE General 1. The navigation dam is an important part of the upgrading to Class III (1,000 dwt vessels) in Hunan waterways. The first phase was finished in 1993. The present dam construction includes a shiplock and a power generating plant. Techno/economic particulars are shown in Table 1. Hydrological, Geological and Meteorological Design Data 2. It was designed by Hunan Design Institute for Communications Planning and Survey. The meteorological design data have been collected from figures of rainfall over the last 30 years. The geological data from the soil investigation have been incorporated in the design of the foundation of the dam and auxiliary works. The hydrological figures for water levels and flows from several stations have been used in the apparent river section. All these data result in an upstream normal-storage water level at Dayuanda dam of 50 m above Yellow Sea level. The maximum head of the dam has been set at 11.24 m (flood season) and minimum head 3.01 m (in dry season). Average season flow has been estimated to be 1,440 m3/s and the design head of the power plant for selection of the generators is 7.5 m. Hydropower Station 3. The Dayuanda hydropower station has been selected as an optimum location in this part of the river. The impact of the energy loss of the upstream hydropower station of Baiyudan dam has been analyzed and taken into account. With the estimated storage level of 50 m (above Yellow Sea level) water head, this part of the river has the most economic power generation. The average yearly generated energy has been calculated to be 483 GWh with an installed capacity of 120 MW. The successive hydropower development in Hunan Province gives a decrease in the power gap between demand and generation of power (Table 2). Selection of Generators 4. The initially selected turbines are of the tubular Kaplan type. In this range of capacity (estimated flow and water head), the Kaplan turbine is most economic with efficiency of more than 90 percent at the rated operating point. The number of generators and the installed capacity has been deduced via sensitivity analyses of different types and
 -62- ANNEX A manufacturers. The analysis shows an optimum in economic investment cost with the 120 MW option. Locally manufactured generators of the Kaplan type have a maximum capacity of 15 MW. Imported generators of former Socialist countries had been selected, being 5 x 24 MW = 120 MW. 5. Now having the opportunity of the World Bank loan, larger sets may be imported from abroad, resulting in the final selection of four sets each of 30 MW bulb turbines. The selected type of generators each have the following main characteristics: diameter of turbine impeller 7.5 m, design head 7.5 m, efficiency at rated operating point 92 percent, rated flow 454 m3/s, annual generated power 556 GWh. 6. By this selection the power generation increases with 4 percent, so more benefits will result. Also foreign technology will give an impact on the technical and scientific development of the knowledge in the HDPC department. Implementation at the Dam Site 7. The location of the powerhouse on the right bank in the outer curve of the river gives better downstream flow. The high-voltage switchyard has been located beside the right bank of the river, downstream of the dam. 8. The outer size of the main building of the powerhouse including assembly area is approximately 130 x 80 x 55 m. The surface area of the switchyard is approximately 130 x 35 m. The shiplock (with dimensions 180 x 23 m and gate-sill water depth 3 m) in the inner curve of the river gives good navigational performance and sufficient waiting area for the 1,000 dwt vessels. Power Distribution Systems 9. The outgoing voltage of 10.5 kV of the four generators will be transformed to 110 kV for the connection to the county grid. The two main transformers each have a capacity of 75 MVA. A separate transformer supplying the site facilities of the generator house, the shiplock, the dam racks and gates is part of the 10 kV system. A distribution transformer in the power station supplies the normal fixtures and outlets of the lighting and power consumers 220/380 V. Transmission Lines 10. To connect the power station with the county grid, high-voltage switchgears for 110 kV supply outgoing overhead transmission lines to other substations upstream and downstream are proposed. Approximately 80 km transmission lines including safety devices and switchgears are part of the project.

 - 79 - ANNEXE ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND ACTION PLAN SUMMARY A. BACKGROUND 1. Environmental assessments (EAs) were carried out for Zhejiang, Hunan and Guangxi project components respectively. EAs for four channels and three ports under the Zhejiang project component were carried out by the Zhejiang Environmental Protection Institute and the Zhejiang Design Institute of Environmental Protection of Light Industry and EA reports were completed by March 1993. Based on the findings of the EAs and subsequent to the discussion with Bank staff, Environmental Action Plans (EAPs) for seven subcomponents were prepared by the Zhejiang Provincial Communications Department (ZPCD) in October 1993 and submitted to the Bank in January 1994. An EA for the Hunan project component was carried out by the Hunan University and completed in August 1993. Based on the findings of the EA reports, an EAP was prepared by the Hunan Provincial Communications Department (HPCD) in September 1993. These documents were submitted to the Bank in January 1994. An EA for the Guangxi project component was carried out by the Guangxi Electric Industry Design Institute in 1990-91. An EA report including supplementary information to meet the Bank requirements, an EAP and an Environmental Monitoring Plan were prepared in English by the Environomics and submnitted to the Bank in February 1994. EA Summaries of Zhejiang, Hunan and Guangxi project components were prepared respectively and submitted to the Bank in May 1994. The EAs, EA Summaries and EAPs were discussed and revised during the appraisal mission in November/December 1994. The final EA Summaries and EAPs were submitted to the Bank in January 1995 and found to be satisfactory to the Bank. 2. A number of potential impacts were identified in the EA process. Regarding channel upgrading in Zhejiang, potential environmental problems include (i) land acquisition for channel widening, (ii) impacts of dredging, (iii) impacts of water pollution on the existing water use, (iv) ship wastes and noise by vessels. Regarding port improvements in Zhejiang and Hunan, potential problems include (i) wastewater and solid wastes from ship and port activities, (ii) impacts on drinking water intake, (iii) wastewater and dust from coalyards, (iv) noise and air pollution including those due to increased land traffic. Regarding dam construction in Hunan and Guangxi, potential problems include (a) impacts of inundation on ecological setting and cultural relics, (b) impacts on water quality in reservoir areas and downstream, (c) impacts on fish and fish migration, (d) impacts of hydrological changes. Regarding waterways regulation and shoal removal in Hunan and Guangxi, potential problems include impacts of blasting and turbidity by shoal removal on fish and aquatic culture.

B. ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT OF ZHEJIANG PROJECT COMPONENT Major Project Components 8. The channel system of northern Zhejiang Province provides an important transportation linkage between major centers in the south of China and Shanghai, and also provides means of transporting raw materials and goods from Zhejiang to Shanghai. The proposed improvements are part of a long-range program to upgrade the inland waterways to Navigational Waterway Class V (300 dwt), thus shifting some of the bulk cargo traffic from highways and railways. 9. The major project components in Zhejiang will include the improvement of four channels by widening/deepening: (i) Hangzhou-Beijing Grand Canal, (ii) Changxing- Huzhou-Shanghai Channel, (iii) Hangzhou-Shanghai Channel, and (iv) Zhapu-Jiaxing- Suzhou Channel. It will also include the construction of terminals in the Hangzhou, Huzhou and Jiaxing Ports. Baseline Environmental Description 10. Geography. The project is located in the northeastem section of Zhejiang Province. The land mass is relatively flat with general drainage from the north to the southeast through mostly agricultural lands. The channels were built in many hundreds years ago and have been widened, deepened and upgraded over the centuries to accommodate larger vessels and increased traffic between the major commercial centers of Guangzhou to the south and Shanghai to the north. 11. Hydrological and Meteorological Conditions. The region belongs to a subtropical monsoon climatic zone, having moist temperature, demarcated seasons and abundant rainfall with the average annual temperature of 15.7C, average humidity of 80 percent and annual precipitation of about 1,200 mm. Occasional typhoons strike in the early Summer and Autumn periods resulting in considerable flooding. The surface drainage goes into the river/waterway network and finally into the Qiantang River and Hangzhou Bay. The river/waterway network is a well developed water transportation network. 12. Population and Economy. The Hangzhou-Huzhou-Jiaxing triangle is the most developed section of Zhejiang Province. In addition to excellent agricultural land, the area is a major silk producer and supplies large quantities of construction materials to
 - 82 - ANNEX E Shanghai. In addition, there are numerous villages/towns, particularly along the channels, reflecting their historical importance in the provincial transportation network. 13. Noise and Air Quality. The proposed channel sections mainly pass through rural and small village areas and may increase local noise levels through vessel engines and horns. In the larger urban centers, particularly Hangzhou and Jiaxing, there have been numerous complaints related to vessel horns and engine noise at night. The air quality ranges from excellent in rural area to fair in urban area. Air quality degradation can be attributed to the handling and combustion of coal (heating and electricity generation) followed by vehicle and shipping exhaust. 14. Water Quality and Sediment. Water quality is poor in many sections of the inland waterways (typically National Water Quality Standards Class 4 or 5) due to the channels being used as receiving water for untreated or minimally treated industrial and sanitary sewage and stormwater discharges. The pollution level of the various waterway sections was classified into four categories: not polluted, slightly, moderately and heavily polluted, based on trace metals concentrations in the sediments. As with water quality, the contamination of sediments was mainly attributed to accumulation of pollutants through various urban and industrial discharges. Potential Impacts and their Mitigation Measures 15. Alternatives. Existing channel alignment was used as much as possible. For sections that need widening, channels will be widened on one side with less land acquisition and relocation of houses. Sites for port terminals were also selected, taking into account of minimizing land acquisition, relocation of houses and adverse environmental impacts. Layout of the port facilities were designed to minimize the adverse impacts on surrounding residential areas. 16. Water Pollution Control. Excavation of materials for channel widening and deepening will be undertaken in two phases. In phase 1, new channel retaining walls are constructed and the material is excavated in the dry condition. This clean soil is utilized to backfill the retaining walls and to in-fill various areas designated for land improvement. In phase 2, the old canal walls and underlying sediments are removed by dredging. Legal Framework 15. Forming the legal basis for land acquisition and resettlement of the Inland Waterways Development Project are both laws or regulations from the state, and implementation measures from provincial and local municipalities. The state laws or regulations include: 'Land Administration Law"(1986), 'City Planning Act"(1990), and 'Administrative Regulation of Urban Building Demolition and Relocation" (1991). The local implementation measures in three provinces include: 'Zhejiang Provincial Implementation Regulation of the Land Administration Law" (1987); 'Guangxi Provincial Implementation Regulation of the Land Administration Law" (1987); 'Hunan Provincial Implementation of the Land Administration Law" (1987) and some related regulations adopted by concerned Municipal governments in three provinces. 16. Under this project, there are two types of land acquisition. One is to acquire rural land from farmers. According to the 'Land Administration Law", section 1, article 2: 'for the public interest, the state could expropriate collectively owned farmland." The essence of the policy is that when the state acquire farmland, the land-using units will pay not only a basic compensation for land, standing crop and attached properties, but also a resettlement compensation (articles 28 of the 'Land Administration Law'). The other type of land acquisition is to acquire land use rights within the urban built-up area, since all urban land are owned by the state. In this case, according to 'Administrative Regulation of Urban Building Demolition and Relocation," the construction unit has to provide adequate compensation or resettlement housing for the displaced families and affected enterprises. 17. Resettlement subsidy for cultivated land acquisition is determined by the number of agricultural population to be resettled. The number is calculated according to the area of acquired land, divided by the average per capita landholding prior to land acquisition within the village or production team. Per resettler subsidy is the average per mu output value three years prior to land acquisition, multiplied by a factor. The Land Law stipulates 2 or 3 as the multiplier and provinces have issued different multipliers according to the size of the per capita landholding. The resettlement compensation could increase up to 10 times the average annual output. If the land compensation and resettlement compensation still cannot guarantee the farmer's original living standard according to regulation, the total land compensation may be increased to a level no more than 20 times the average annual output value per mu in the three years before acquisition. A detailed breakdown of the land acquisition compensation is presented in the next section.

doc.abstracts: The Inland Waterways Project will: (a) improve Inland Waterways (IWW) management and introduce organizational and financial reforms in line with a market economy; (b) expand IWW capacity by widening and deepening channels to improve navigation, which requires constructing dams to increase the water level; (c) improve connections between IWW and land transport services by appropriately equipping IWW ports; (d) generate hydroelectric power by utilizing the indifferential heads at the dams; and (e) enhance the capabilities of the IWW entities. Two of the project provinces - Hunan and Guangxi - are relatively poor, and project investments are expected to promote economic development there by helping to create new jobs, increase incomes and reduce poverty. The project's multisectoral strategy is consistent with the financial goals of the Government's IWW reforms policies, and addresses the lack of intersectoral coordination that reduced the IWW network in the past.
